*''Boletus legaliae'' Pilát (1968) *''Boletus satanoides'' sensu auct. mult. *''Boletus spinari'' Hlaváček (2000) }} {{mycomorphbox | name = ''Rubroboletus legaliae'' | whichGills = adnate | capShape = convex | hymeniumType = pores | stipeCharacter = bare | ecologicalType = mycorrhizal | sporePrintColor = olive-brown | howEdible = poisonous }} '''''Rubroboletus legaliae''''', previously known as ''Boletus splendidus'', ''B. satanoides'', and ''B. legaliae'' is a [[basidiomycete]] [[fungus]] of the family [[Boletaceae]]. It is [[Mushroom poisoning|poisonous]], with predominantly [[gastrointestinal symptom]]s, and is related to ''[[Rubroboletus satanas]]''. ==Taxonomy== ''Boletus legaliae'' was [[species description|described]] by Czech [[mycologist]] [[Albert Pilát]] in 1968. It is named after the French mycologist [[Marcelle Le Gal]].{{cite web |author= Bernard Crozes |url= http://mycostra.free.fr/bulletin/femmes_mycologues.htm |title= Les femmes mycologues |accessdate= 2008-07-04 |publisher= Mycological Society of Strasbourg |language= French }} ''Boletus splendidus'' as described by Charles-Édouard Martín in 1894 is a [[synonym (taxonomy)|synonym]]. The description of ''Boletus satanoides'' was too vague to be ascribed to any actual species. ''Boletus legaliae'' was transferred to the genus ''[[Rubroboletus]]'' in 2015 by Marco Della Maggiora and Renzo Trassinelli. ==Description== The [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] is initially off-white, or coffee-coloured at the button stage. In mid life it often (but not always) turns a pale mouse grey. In old age the cap turns reddish, or what has been described as 'old rose'.{{cite book | author = Régis Courtecuisse | author2 = Bernard Duhem | last-author-amp = yes | year = 1995 | title = Mushrooms and Toadstools of Britain and Europe | publisher = Harper Collins | isbn = 0-00-220025-2}} It may reach {{convert|14|cm|in|round=0.5|abbr=on}} in diameter. The [[stipe (mycology)|stipe]] is stocky, with a narrow red reticulation (net pattern) on an orange ground at the apex. This orange ground colour fades gradually towards the midsection, making the red reticulation more pronounced. At the base the reticulation is absent, and the [[stipe (mycology)|stipe]] turns dark [[wine (color)|vinaceous]]. Sometimes the stipe detail can be faint, or even absent when covered with earth or leaf litter. The pores are initially red, but have an overall orange colour when mature, and they bruise blue. The flesh turns pale blue on cutting / dark vinaceous in the stipe base. The flesh is said to smell of [[chicory]].{{cite book | author = Marcel Bon | year = 1987 | title = The Mushrooms and Toadstools of Britain and North Western Europe | publisher = Hodder and Stoughton | isbn = 0-340-39935-X}} ===Similar species=== ''[[Rubroboletus satanas]]'', found in broad-leaved woodland on calcareous soil, has a whiter [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] that turns brownish-ochre, lacking the overall reddish tones in maturity. It has a more nauseating smell, and it is poisonous, possibly deadly.{{cite book | author = Roger Phillips | year = 2006 | title = Mushrooms | publisher = Pan MacMillan | isbn = 0-330-44237-6}} Molecular study of the holotype of ''[[Rubroboletus spinari]]'' has demonstrated its conspecifity with '''''Rubroboletus legaliae'''''. ==Distribution and habitat== Uncommon in [[Southern England]], and [[Europe]]. Grows with oak (''[[Quercus]]'') and beech (''[[Beech|Fagus]]'') often on neutral to acid soils. It is considered [[vulnerable species|vulnerable]] in the Czech Republic. ==Toxicity== Edibility testing resulted in a strong gastrointestinal upset, which is typically caused by ''[[Rubroboletus]]'' species when eaten raw. ==Group status== In Britain, all of the boletes in the '''''Satanas''''' group are either very rare, endangered, or extinct.
